title: Jack Riewoldt on poltical uncertainty threatening Tasmania Devils | The Examiner
body_text:
Tasmania Football Club ambassador Jack Riewoldt has warned it could be now or never for the Devils' AFL dream.

With the club's AFL licence in the balance due to the ongoing leadership debate in Tasmanian Parliament, the 347-game, three-time premiership player was passionate about the state's future.
"These things don't come around very often, and who's to say it might come around ever again if this is not the time for it?" he said.
"But that would be extremely disappointing and hopefully we are not having that conversation.
"It's critically important for us to exist, and we will find out what will go on.
"But we are so driven to putting the best product out there on-field and off-field to make sure it represents all of Tasmania and all Tasmanians and the 210,000 that have signed up to be Devils members."
Tasmanian opposition leader Dean Winter tabled a no-confidence motion against Premier Jeremy Rockliff, which was supported by the Greens, putting the state on the path to an early election.
There are fears an early election would pose a risk to progress on the Macquarie Point stadium, which in turn could kill off the Tasmanian AFL team.
"The big thing is that politics is politics," Riewoldt said.
"The club continues to focus on what we can control, but the big thing is that the contract is there with the AFL and it's been clearly stated about what's in that and what's required for the Devils to play in the men's and women's competition.
"We have a job to do to prepare ourselves and prepare this team to represent Tasmania, and we can't influence anyone at the moment; they'll decide what they want to do for us.
"It's all eyes on the road, continue to look forward to season 2028 for our men's and women's teams."
When asked what he would say to decision-makers behind the Devils' dream and the Macquarie Point stadium, Riewoldt remained neutral, and said he would discuss the matter and it's their decision.
He then pointed towards what TFC wants to do and what they've done so far in uniting Tasmania.
"We know that there's so many different issues that need to be solved here in Tasmania, and my belief and the belief of the club is that we are not just a footy club, we are a community organisation," he said.
"I say we've got to have our eyes on the road [and] other issues around the state are a part of that.
"We want to help make sure that Tasmania is great and we continue to produce athletes like myself, like [186-time world woodchopping champion] David [Foster], and we continue to give opportunities for our next generation to be the best versions of themselves, best versions of Tasmanians and we can be the best state we can be."
Riewoldt's appearance at the Tasmania Devils' press conference was announced before the no-confidence motion was tabled, speaking alongside general manager of marketing Kath McCann.
McCann broke down during questioning on the Devils' future, turning away from the microphones to compose herself before explaining what the club's impact on the next generation has meant to her.
